items.title: Marco Rubio warns Israel not to annex West Bank after Knesset vote in favour
items.standfirst: US secretary of state says preliminary move to apply Israeli law in occupied land is ‘counterproductive’ and a threat to peaceMiddle East crisis – live updatesThe US secretary of state, Marco Rubio, on Wednesday warned Israel against annexing the West Bank, calling lawmakers’ preliminary vote to extend sovereignty in the occupied area and the surge in settler violence there a “threat to peace.”A bill applying Israeli law to the occupied West Bank, a move tantamount to the annexation of land Palestinians want for a state, won preliminary approval from Israel’s parliament on Wednesday, barely a week after Donald Trump pushed through a deal aimed at ending a two-year Israeli offensive in Gaza. Continue reading...

Rubio is the latest US official to visit Israel in a bid to shore up the shaky, US-brokered truce.

items.title: Cuba arrests alleged Chinese fentanyl kingpin who escaped custody in Mexico
items.standfirst: Zhi Dong Zhang, known by alias ‘Brother Wang’, is also wanted by US and has alleged ties to Mexican drug cartelsCuba has arrested an alleged Chinese fentanyl kingpin who escaped custody in Mexico in July and is also wanted by the US, Mexican security sources told AFP on Wednesday.Zhi Dong Zhang, known by the alias “Brother Wang” and with alleged ties to Mexico’s Sinaloa and Jalisco New Generation drug cartels, will remain in Cuba awaiting a decision on his possible extradition, the sources added. Continue reading...
items.content: Zhi Dong Zhang, known by alias ‘Brother Wang’, is also wanted by US and has alleged ties to Mexican drug cartelsCuba has arrested an alleged Chinese fentanyl kingpin who escaped custody in Mexico in July and is also wanted by the US, Mexican security sources told AFP on Wednesday.Zhi Dong Zhang, known by the alias “Brother Wang” and with alleged ties to Mexico’s Sinaloa and Jalisco New Generation drug cartels, will remain in Cuba awaiting a decision on his possible extradition, the sources added. items.standfirst: Tie-up between Airbus, Leonardo and Thales will bring together some of continent’s leading manufacturersAirbus, Leonardo and Thales have struck a deal to combine their space businesses to create a single European technology company that could rival Elon Musk’s SpaceX.The deal is expected to create a company with annual revenue of about €6.5bn (£5.6bn). The French aerospace company Airbus will own 35% of the new business, with Leonardo and Thales each owning stakes of 32.5%. Continue reading...

clusters.title: European leaders are meeting in Brussels to discuss about Ukraine support
clusters.neutral_headline: EU Discusses Ukraine Support in Brussels
bullet_summary: Reported by France24, Guardian World

items.title: European leaders are meeting in Brussels to discuss about Ukraine support
items.standfirst: European leaders are set to meet Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky in Brussels to reaffirm their support for Kyiv amid uncertainty over stalled US peace efforts with Russia. The EU has agreed on a new sanctions package targeting Moscow, including a ban on Russian liquefied natural gas from 2027 and restrictions on oil tankers and Chinese refineries. Leaders also endorsed using frozen Russian assets to provide a €140 billion “reparation loan” to Ukraine. Zelensky is urging quick approval, stressing Ukraine needs the funds by year’s end with flexibility on how to use them. France24 Europe Editor Armen Georgian reports the latest from Brussels.
items.content: European leaders are set to meet Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky in Brussels to reaffirm their support for Kyiv amid uncertainty over stalled US peace efforts with Russia. The EU has agreed on a new sanctions package targeting Moscow, including a ban on Russian liquefied natural gas from 2027 and restrictions on oil tankers and Chinese refineries. Leaders also endorsed using frozen Russian assets to provide a €140 billion “reparation loan” to Ukraine. Zelensky is urging quick approval, stressing Ukraine needs the funds by year’s end with flexibility on how to use them. France24 Europe Editor Armen Georgian reports the latest from Brussels.

items.title: EU has a plan to use frozen Russian assets to fund Ukraine – how will it work?
items.standfirst: What are the legal implications, and why does Belgium fear being left alone with the bill?Latest EU sanctions against Russia target liquified natural gasWith Donald Trump ruling out further US military aid, and as Russia’s deadly attacks grind on, European leaders are looking for a new way to finance the defence of Ukraine.Now they think they have an answer: using billions of Russian state assets frozen in the west. Continue reading...
items.content: What are the legal implications, and why does Belgium fear being left alone with the bill?Latest EU sanctions against Russia target liquified natural gasWith Donald Trump ruling out further US military aid, and as Russia’s deadly attacks grind on, European leaders are looking for a new way to finance the defence of Ukraine.Now they think they have an answer: using billions of Russian state assets frozen in the west. Continue reading...

items.title: Live: EU adopts new sanctions against Russia ahead of Brussels summit
items.standfirst: The EU on Thursday adopted a 19th package of sanctions against Russia for its war against Ukraine that includes a ban on Russian liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports. It came as EU leaders are meeting at a summit in Brussels in a bid to shore up support for Ukraine by advancing a plan to use frozen Russian assets to fund a “reparation loan” for Kyiv. Follow our live blog for the latest developments.
items.content: The EU on Thursday adopted a 19th package of sanctions against Russia for its war against Ukraine that includes a ban on Russian liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports. It came as EU leaders are meeting at a summit in Brussels in a bid to shore up support for Ukraine by advancing a plan to use frozen Russian assets to fund a “reparation loan” for Kyiv. Follow our live blog for the latest developments.

ai_summary: European leaders met in Brussels to discuss Ukraine support.
The EU agreed on a new sanctions package against Russia.
The package includes a ban on Russian liquefied natural gas.
Leaders endorsed using frozen Russian assets for a loan.
Zelensky is urging quick approval for the funds.

clusters.title: US military strikes suspected drug vessels in the eastern Pacific ocean
clusters.neutral_headline: US Military Strikes Alleged Drug Boats
bullet_summary: On Wednesday afternoon, Hegseth said the military attacked a vessel in the eastern Pacific Ocean and killed two men on Tuesday
Reported by France24, Guardian World

items.title: US military strikes suspected drug vessels in the eastern Pacific ocean
items.standfirst: The US military killed five alleged drug smugglers in strikes against two vessels in the eastern Pacific Ocean, US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said on Wednesday, in an expansion of the Trump administration's use of the armed forces in its counter-narcotics campaign. On Wednesday afternoon, Hegseth said the military attacked a vessel in the eastern Pacific Ocean and killed two men on Tuesday. It was the first known US military operation in the Pacific since President Donald Trump kicked off a new offensive against the drug trade. France24 International Affairs Editor Andrew Hilliar gives his insights.
items.content: The US military killed five alleged drug smugglers in strikes against two vessels in the eastern Pacific Ocean, US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said on Wednesday, in an expansion of the Trump administration's use of the armed forces in its counter-narcotics campaign. On Wednesday afternoon, Hegseth said the military attacked a vessel in the eastern Pacific Ocean and killed two men on Tuesday. It was the first known US military operation in the Pacific since President Donald Trump kicked off a new offensive against the drug trade. France24 International Affairs Editor Andrew Hilliar gives his insights.

items.title: US military kills five people in strikes on alleged drug-trafficking boats in Pacific
items.standfirst: Latest strikes were off coast of Colombia, while seven previous attacks in Caribbean killed at least 32The US military has for the first time attacked and destroyed two boats on the Pacific side of South America, as part of its controversial fight against what it says are drug-trafficking activities.The strikes – on Tuesday night and then early on Wednesday – killed five people, according to the US defence secretary, Pete Hegseth. They came on top of at least seven other strikes in the Caribbean that have killed at least 32 people and raised tensions with Colombia and Venezuela. Continue reading...
items.content: Latest strikes were off coast of Colombia, while seven previous attacks in Caribbean killed at least 32The US military has for the first time attacked and destroyed two boats on the Pacific side of South America, as part of its controversial fight against what it says are drug-trafficking activities.The strikes – on Tuesday night and then early on Wednesday – killed five people, according to the US defence secretary, Pete Hegseth. They came on top of at least seven other strikes in the Caribbean that have killed at least 32 people and raised tensions with Colombia and Venezuela. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The US military killed five people in strikes on drug boats.
The strikes occurred in the eastern Pacific Ocean.
The strikes were off the coast of Colombia.
Seven previous attacks in the Caribbean killed at least 32 people.
The US Defense Secretary confirmed the strikes.

items.title: Gaza: 54 unidentified Palestinian bodies returned for mass burial
items.standfirst: A collective funeral was held on Wednesday in Deir al-Balah, central Gaza, for 54 unidentified Palestinians whose bodies were returned from Israel, the Palestinian Civil Defense (PCD) said. The PCD noted that many of the bodies could not be identified by their families because of the harsh conditions surrounding their deaths. Gabrielle Nadler has the latest.

The PCD noted that many of the bodies could not be identified by their families because of the harsh conditions surrounding their deaths. Gabrielle Nadler has the latest.
